Erik Wilde (@dret): REST Community Service

(2) Summary

REST is all about designing and deploying services in a global decentralized shared space for information and services. The set of shared concepts used in this landscape is constantly evolving. One slow but important aspect of this ongoing evolution is standardization, a process that is necessarily slow, can be contentious, and requires quite a bit of energy and willingness to listen. Nevertheless, as part of the ongoing effort to make the Internet and the Web more useful for everybody, it is important that (some) members of the community participate in standardization.

Standards are Languages Erik Wilde (@dret): REST Community Service

(7) Language Matters

  • APIs are languages
  • Representations are language sentences
  • Design and document the language of each API
  • Webby design should use language composition
  • Reusing/composing vocabularies helps with interoperability


Standards are Languages Erik Wilde (@dret): REST Community Service

(8) The Web Vocabulary



Standards are Languages Erik Wilde (@dret): REST Community Service

(9) Extending the Web Surface

  • Adding concept values reflects new things to talk about
  • Adding concepts reflects new classes of things to talk about
  • A good pattern is to connect languages (and possibly make them extensible)
    • Make a new concept discoverable via an existing one (Link HTTP Header field [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-header/Link])
    • Establish a concept by defining/managing its value space (IANA link relation type registry [https://www.iana.org/assignments/link-relations/link-relations.xhtml#link-relations-1])
    • The value space can be used for further extensions of the Web surface

(12) Standards vs. Documentation



Scope Erik Wilde (@dret): REST Community Service

(13) Standard Anti-Patterns

  • The Goldberg [https://www.rubegoldberg.com/] Standard
    • Do one thing rather complicated and in a hard-to-change way
  • The Pie in the Sky Standard
    • Instead of doing one thing, build a framework for getting things done
  • The Hypervertical Standard
    • Do something so specific that it's unlikely to see much reuse


Scope Erik Wilde (@dret): REST Community Service

(14) Understand the Context

  • Who am I?
  • Understand the complexity
  • Understand the complication/confusion


Scope Erik Wilde (@dret): REST Community Service

(15) Standards are Languages and not the Truth



Scope Erik Wilde (@dret): REST Community Service

(16) Pick Your Battles

  • Identify the key aspects that matter for you
  • Be ready to compromise on non-essential aspects
  • Language utility is mostly a function of the user base

Organizations Erik Wilde (@dret): REST Community Service

(18) Standard Types [https://www.safaribooksonline.com/library/view/restful-web-apis/9781449359713/pr05.html]

  • Fiat standards: Why not do it this way?
  • Personal standards: I like the way this has been done.
  • Corporate standards: Let's try to figure out a way to do this.
  • Open standards: Hello everybody! Let's solve this problem!


Organizations Erik Wilde (@dret): REST Community Service

(22) Just Get Started

  • Expect to get some pushback
  • Expect to adjust the scope
  • Expect it to go slowly
  • Help the community by still doing it


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): REST Community Service
